thread.title: Surf lifesavers concerned over shark fishing near WA beach
thread.title_full: Surf lifesavers concerned over shark fishing near WA beach

author: Sarah Taillier
title: Surf lifesavers concerned over shark fishing near WA beach

organizations.name: champion bay surf live saving club

text:
Map: Geraldton 6530 
Surf lifesavers are concerned that targeted shark fishing is attracting predators to a popular swimming beach in regional Western Australia. 
It has surfaced that anglers have been hooking sharks off a rock groyne at Geraldton, 400 kilometres north of Perth, and landing some of their catch on one of the city's main recreational beaches. 
Images posted on social media show a beached shark metres away from the local surf lifesaving club. Photo: Peter Nelson, president of Geraldton's Champion Bay Surf Live Saving Club, says shark hunters are putting large baits in the water. (ABC News: Sebastian Neuweiler) 
Club president, Peter Nelson, said shark hunters were putting large baits in the water and fishing "about as close as you can get" to the popular swimming beach. 
"If they do it regularly then I suppose the sharks get to realise that there's free food in that area," he said. 
"I would think that would tend to attract more sharks into that area." 
Mr Nelson wrote to the City of Greater Geraldton (CGG) and proposed a potential ban on targeted shark fishing in the area. Seeking advice on the matter 
CGG Mayor Shane Van Styn said the city was gathering information on the matter. 
"Clearly, pulling sharks up on town beach is not a desirable outcome and we'll look to see if any action is necessary," he said. Photo: WA Premier Colin Barnett has pledged $200,000 to establish a shark net off Geraldton. (ABC Open: Chris Lewis) 
Mr Van Styn said there could be grounds to create a local law against deliberate shark fishing in the area but said it would be hard to police. 
"If we had a local law that said there would be no shark fishing then we could act by way of infringement," he said. 
"I don't know how you'd start to know if someone was actually fishing for a shark or fishing for a large mulloway; very similar techniques are used." 
Mr Van Styn said he would be seeking more advice on the matter and consulting with stakeholders. Liberals promise shark barrier 
Interest in shark mitigation at the Mid West city had swelled in recent weeks, after WA's Premier Colin Barnett promised that Geraldton would receive a shark barrier if the Liberal government was re-elected in the upcoming state election. 
At the time, Mr Barnett said the barrier would boost tourism. 
Mr Van Styn is concerned that images posted on social media, of fishers posing with beached sharks on Geraldton's foreshore, could turn tourists away. 
"I'm certainly not impressed by seeing pictures of tiger sharks being brought up near Surf Life Saving Club facilities," he said. 
"I don't think it helps our tourism image at all."
